title: Photoelectric - slope of stopping V vs frequency

content.question: Two metal plates inside a vacuum are connected to a variable source of potential difference, as shown in the figure. One of the plates is illuminated by monochromatic light that causes electrons <math alttext="open parenthesis, e, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><mtext>e</mtext><mo>)</mo></math> to be emitted, creating an electric current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math>. The potential difference <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> between the plates is gradually increased until <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> is measured to be zero at a potential difference of <math alttext="V sub I equals 0, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mrow><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></math>. In the graph to the right of the figure, the solid line shows how <math alttext="V sub I equals 0, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mrow><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></math> varies as a function of the frequency <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> of the incident light, while the dashed line indicates an extension of the solid line into the region below the horizontal axis. As indicated, <math alttext="V sub I equals 0, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mrow><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></math> is equal to <math alttext="V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> when light of frequency <math alttext="f sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is incident on the top plate, which has a work function <math alttext="phi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ϕ</mi></math>. What is the slope of the solid line in the graph?

choices.label: <math alttext="the complex fraction with numerator V sub 1, end sub, plus the fraction phi over e, and denominator f sub 1, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>e</mi></mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></math>

<math alttext="the complex fraction with numerator V sub 1, end sub, minus the fraction phi over e, and denominator f sub 1, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>−</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>e</mi></mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></math>

<math alttext="the fraction with numerator e V sub 1, end sub, plus phi, and denominator f sub 1, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><mi>e</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>ϕ</mi></mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></math>

<math alttext="the fraction with numerator e V sub 1, end sub, minus phi, and denominator f sub 1, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><mi>e</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>−</mo><mi>ϕ</mi></mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="the complex fraction with numerator V sub 1, end sub, plus the fraction phi over e, and denominator f sub 1, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>e</mi></mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></math>
